content: @WG-async-foundations :wave:

3 things got done this week:

  • Impossible case reached: src/librustc_ty/needs_drop.rs:111 #72685
  • Stabilize the Wake trait #74304
  • Unhelpful "cannot infer type" error for ? in async block with unclear Result Err type #77880
(sorry, got distracted by something)
No new issues!
Any other updates?
I have been trying to get the must_not_suspend rfc moving again.
I mentioned a couple of reviewers, though not sure what else I can do
gimme the link again :)
https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/3014
Update: About to land https://github.com/rust-lang/async-book/pull/124 - an update to the "Why async" section in the book. Approved and reviewed, just proof-reading atm.
so @Didrik Nordstrom
is book discussion happening in this stream or somewhere else :)
I have some thoughts I'd like to share, though I can just dump them here
#wg-async-foundations/book <-- this stream exists I guess

anyway what I wanted to say is: I've been thinking about the idea of having a good "intro to async-await' in the book. In the past, I was also feeling stymied because there are so many options for runtimes and I don't want us to "embrace" just one of them
at the same time, I think that having the book call out to other tutorials is a bit unfortunate, it'd be great if we could help get people going from a single source
so I had a few thoughts recently
One of them is that we could create a dummy runtime that is intentionally very naive. That has the problem that people are learning to use this runtime that they'll never want to use.
Another is that we could extend mdbook to have multiple "flavors" of the book for different runtimes
and then we could let people submit their own ports, which is kinda neat
I was thinking of the way that the microsoft pages let you pick different .net languages
curious to hear what people think about that
I think in the longer term, if we could have a common interface for the runtimes, then the documentation and materials could be generic across them.
Thanks for the link to the stream, I'll make use of that. I've been starting ad-hoc threads here.
sure
in the longer term
but I think that's quite a ways away
I agree
Tyler mentioned some of these thoughts. I agree with the sentiment too.
We talked about having a thread pool backed wrappers of std in such a runtime, which gives you file IO, networking and timers (which are currently missing from the futures executor)
yes, that is an option
and I'm still keen-ish on it
though i think longer term I prefer the "multiple runtimes" variant
(it sounds like you're describing the "naive runtime" I was proposing)
Yes
We currently use async-std in the final project section btw.
ah, interesting
I guess that
I would be totally happy to just have multiple branches of that chapter
if anybody cared to submit one for another runtime

Basically, a naive runtime would make us more comfortable in using it for the book, but I'm not convinced that's currently the limiting factor for the book providing good intro to async in practice. Not at all against the idea, just from a prioritization perspective.
this is what @jamesmcm did here and it worked quite well
I enjoyed comparing the two branches
also I think that intro is a good template for inclusion in the book
I'll check that post, thanks.
presuming @jamesmcm doesn't mind :)
Am I understanding you correctly that you want more and better hands-on tutorial-type of material in the book, and the runtime is a vector to achieve that?
yes
I want there to be a "go to" source that helps people get started
and I think it makes sense for the rust org to provide that
(I'd be interested if folks disagree)
ideally it would map well to examples from the rust book

Cool, yes. I agree with the aim. I will say that I think there is a lot of work in that direction that could be done simply by following the same patterns currently in the book (more and better content - basically)
it seems like you've been leadin this effort to improve the book
are other people working on it?

nikomatsakis said:

ideally it would map well to examples from the rust book

Yes, that's what we did with the final project. Mirroring the regular book (@Lee Bernick did the work)

nikomatsakis said:

I would be totally happy to just have multiple branches of that chapter

this would be a good way to bootstrap the approach.. maybe we can use mdbook's include feature to provide the same prose content in each "branch" with different code samples
yep

nikomatsakis said:

are other people working on it?

Lee, as I said, has been contributing! Otherwise, I've gotten feedback, reviews, help, but afaik nobody else is writing and making large refactors.
Which runtimes would you want to see? async-std/smol/tokio?
If we do that.
what I wnat to do is
provide a way for other people to contribute alternative runtimes
put another way, I think I'd prefer to start by getting the content with some runtime
but with some disclaimers and links to how folks can contribute ports
Ok, that seems like a good start, we're on track there I think with the final project.
I don't really have a strong opinon about which one we use and would be ok with letting people do the one they prefer
although I think we should probably be consistent
i.e., if we only have one ... ?
i.e., I presume that @Lee Bernick picked their personal fave and that's cool with me :)

I don't know if you've checked, but Lee has also added a section about the ecosystem which explains some of the next steps that you'd need to take and caveats with picking a runtime. https://rust-lang.github.io/async-book/08_ecosystem/00_chapter.html
I did see that
I was skimming the book a bit
i think the main thing i would change is a link in this section
or even a whole section
that links to this section listing runtimes and makes a point to repeat that this is for explanatory purposes
and that we would welcome an effort to extend the book to support multiple runtimes

My current priority after this PR lands is to better differentiate between using async and understanding everything about executors, futures, wakers etc. I view the current state (basically - digging into the "under the hood" immediately after the introduction) as advanced content that should be separated clearly.
agreed
I think it's very valuable
but it comes too early
it's more the "middle phase" of learning

nikomatsakis said:

i think the main thing i would change is a link in this section

Not sure I follow. Adding links to the runtimes when mentioned?
Ah I see now.

nikomatsakis said:

it's more the "middle phase" of learning

the second stage, in the categories of Terry Tao

Didrik Nordstrom said:

Ah I see now.

do you want me to elaborate, or is it clear?

where it now says

Adding an Async Runtime

Here, we'll use an executor from the async-std crate.
Clear.
I'm imagining

Aside: choosing a runtime

Before you can do i/O blah blah blah you must pick a runtime. See here for a list. We are using async-std but we're interested in extending the book to cover multiple runtimes. If you think that's a project yo'd like to undertake, reach out on Zulip!

Adding an async runtime

Here, we'll use an executor from the async-std crate...
something like that
maybe even a whole chapter (e.g., 9.1) so it's very prominent :)

[...] the categories of Terry Tao

Bookmarking :)

nikomatsakis said:

something like that

Sounds good, I'll make sure me or Lee takes care of it. Thanks for the feedback.
Thanks all.

Sorry I missed this discussion! I really like the idea of allowing people to choose a runtime and then displaying code examples in that runtime. Is there other content or examples you'd like to see in the book as well? In terms of the simple change you mentioned to this section I can do that pretty easily. @nikomatsakis @Didrik Nordstrom

Thanks @Lee Bernick. I'm open to "multiple runtimes", but we should think a bit - and/or look at prior art - to make sure we get that right. I like to print or export to PDF/kindle, where there is no interactivity. Interactivity makes multi-format a little trickier. Mdbook supports epub and "man-page-like" text output today, so we can't just add a naive JS toggle.
https://docs.rs/mdbook/0.4.6/mdbook/book/index.html
Good point, noted
